paragraphs.name: e9c3
paragraphs.text: The answer is between 5–7 years, depending on whether you calculate figures like “nine times your monthly income” as pretax or post-tax. (It’s supposed to be pretax, but maybe I can count post-tax as a sub-goal. I pay a lot of taxes.)

paragraphs.name: 6ffa
paragraphs.text: The second thing I did after finishing the book was use Anderson’s worksheets—yes, this book has worksheets that I converted into spreadsheets, it’s delightful—to figure out how long it will take me to get from Independence to Freedom, assuming a 15 percent savings rate.

Although that last paragraph makes it sound like I have enough money to save 30 percent or more, I’m in a freelance earnings downswing at the moment and saving 15 percent pretax is going to be hard. I did the math for the next two months: adding 5 percent to my savings rate, plus my basic expenses and business expenses, pretty much pulls all the extra money out of my budget. This means I won’t be able to indulge in even the modest items on my Wants List: no new shoes, no new set of sheets, definitely no new sofa. It also means that, if I want to save 15 percent of my income and make it sustainable, I need to earn a little more money every month. (Which I can probably do.)

5de4571e58eb.title: Freedom by 40 is my bf’s life goal and I think he can make it happen.

paragraphs.text: Freedom by 40 is my bf’s life goal and I think he can make it happen. I can possibly make it happen since I’ve got 8 years to go!

6182e7a9eae.title: I think the answer would be “pay down debt less aggressively,” but you’d have to do the math in the…

paragraphs.name: 1b75
paragraphs.text: I think the answer would be “pay down debt less aggressively,” but you’d have to do the math in the book to find out. The idea might be that you could get more value out of your money if you didn’t put such a large percentage of it towards your debt. BUT READ THE BOOK I am not a financial adviser.

932628b8ede6.title: Although this assumes your pre-tax earnings stay flat over the next 5–7 years; if they increase it…

paragraphs.name: 4c62
paragraphs.text: Although this assumes your pre-tax earnings stay flat over the next 5–7 years; if they increase it will be longer, won’t it?

5b2d84fd301b.title: Hmm, okay, I will definitely get the book.

paragraphs.name: 0b97
paragraphs.text: Hmm, okay, I will definitely get the book. I’m paying a 4% variable rate on $37k in student loans; 5–6% fixed rate on a variety of federal student loans totaling less than $5k; and a 3% (variable) rate on my home equity line on which I owe $130k. So I’d like to pay down the variable loans before the rates increase much further!

paragraphs.text: Don’t rack up credit card debt; if you have credit card debt, paying it off is high-priority, because so it’s so *bleep!*-ing expensive.

paragraphs.text: Innnnteresting. I will definitely have to pick this up. Right now my savings is just… sitting there (I am well into Independence but nowhere near Freedom by these metrics). I suspect I am not contributing nearly enough of my salary to retirement or savings (most of my savings is from a book advance, I just dumped that in there and never spent it)…

paragraphs.name: 8d48
paragraphs.text: One suggestion: If you’re a freelander and making decent money as a solo entrepreneur, you ought to look at incorporating yourself. All those taxes you pay could be greatly reduced as activities you can’t deduct today become tax-deductible business expenses. In fact, an an S-corporation, you can pay yourself a salary…

8fcf10fe872a.title: If reading the book has changed the priority from spending to saving, then it’s a very good result.

paragraphs.name: ecfd
paragraphs.text: If reading the book has changed the priority from spending to saving, then it’s a very good result. IMHO, buying assets which generate income will be a better financial result for you than sofas and sheets. If you’re currently in your mid-30s, getting passive income streams working for you is starting to become urgent.

d861788ae82f.title: it’s a pain the first year, but it may make sense to set you up as an s-corp?

paragraphs.text: it’s a pain the first year, but it may make sense to set you up as an s-corp? I’m sure you’ve researched it, and I think I remember you mentioning it in a previous post, but as a person who just signed taxes last night, it’s on my mind. we paid significantly lower taxes vs paying self-employment taxes [that extra 12.5% is a doozy] but it depends on…

d1de5d14f2a0.title: I requested this book from the library.

paragraphs.text: I requested this book from the library. I’m hoping that it can answer my biggest question which is should I be putting my savings into retirement or some other vehicle, and if something else, what? I’m saving the “right” percentage but am always convinced I’m not doing the right things with it.

virtuals.subtitle: Also, go get The Value of Debt from the library, it does math to debt to tell you whether it’s benefiting you or not.

paragraphs.name: 6fc6
paragraphs.text: This feels like very relevant advice. I was putting $1,000+ towards student loans for months before realizing that it was probably not in my best interest to do so because, in theory*, I’d never actually have to pay those loans back in full ever. I’d likely either be covered by public service loan forgiveness (10 years), or income-based repayment…

5b352d603687.title: All these “but maybe being completely out of debt isn’t the answer” articles lately are messing…

paragraphs.name: 04ff
paragraphs.text: All these “but maybe being completely out of debt isn’t the answer” articles lately are messing with my head! I have $25k in a savings account and $40k in my 401k. Also, another $1k or so invested in the stock market. I owe $40k in student loans and $130k on my mortgage (on a house worth 4ook). No credit card debt. I’ve been aggressively paying down…
